CeO₂–Fe₂O₃ binary oxides were effectively incorporated into mesoporous spherical silica (MCM-41) via a sol–gel technique. The resultant CFO/MCM-41 nanocomposites, with metal loadings ranging from 3 to 30 wt%, were subsequently calcined at 550 °C and assessed as catalysts for the gas-phase dehydration of isobutyl alcohol. Structural and surface analyses using XRD, TG-DTA, ATR-FTIR, BET, TEM, EDX, XPS, and pyridine-adsorbed FTIR confirmed the formation of thermally stable, well-dispersed active phases, as well as the presence of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The differences in catalytic activity among these nanocomposites were closely linked to variations in their acidity. Among all the catalysts, the 10 wt% CeFeO₃/MCM-41 sample demonstrated the best performance at 350 °C, achieving approximately 92 % isobutanol conversion, 100 % selectivity toward isobutylene, and a butene production rate of 45.10 mmol g⁻¹ h⁻¹ . The catalyst also showed excellent stability across five reuse cycles. The outstanding catalytic performance and stability were directly correlated with the material's enhanced structural integrity and optimized textural properties. Furthermore, XPS analysis revealed that the Ce3 +/Ce4+ and Fe2+/Fe3+ redox states, modulated by Ce–Fe interactions, played a crucial role in tuning the catalyst’s acidity and catalytic performance. Graphical Abstract Keywords Binary oxides Mesoporous silica Nanocomposite IBA Butylene Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Butanol has valuable applications in fuel and chemical industries [1]. It can be converted into high-value compounds like butyraldehyde, butyric acid, esters, and ethers [2] or upgraded via dehydration to produce 1-butene, which further transforms into C4 olefins [3]. Since C4 olefins are mainly obtained as by-products from FCC units, their rising demand highlights the need for sustainable production. Additionally, butanol conversion plays a key role in the alcohol-to-jet-fuel process, where C4 olefins are oligomerized and hydrogenated to produce jet fuel [4]. Butenes are fundamental chemical building blocks used in the production of various commodities and fuel additives [5]. The oligomers formed from these light olefins serve as key feed stocks for manufacturing lubricants, motor fuels, dyes, detergents, and fuel improvers [6]. Due to the increasing demand for petrochemical feedstocks, there has been growing interest in the dehydration of butanol to butenes [7,8]. These butenes can be transformed into fuels and fuel additives through oligomerization using appropriate solid acid catalysts [9] For instance, 1-butene (1-BUY) is extensively utilized in oligomerization and polymerization processes, either independently or in combination with more reactive light olefins like ethylene and propylene, to synthesize polymeric materials [10]. Additionally, the dimerization of butenes yields oxygen- and sulfur-free fuel additives that improve the octane rating of gasoline [11,12]. Producing butenes from bio-butanol, derived from renewable and sustainable sources, offers considerable economic and environmental advantages. The catalyst's acidity, whether of the Brønsted or Lewis type, is considered crucial in influencing its catalytic performance in this process. Enhancing the efficiency of dehydration catalysts largely relies on optimizing their acidic properties, including their quantity and type (Brønsted or Lewis). Additionally, the activity and selectivity are significantly influenced by the nature of the support and the strength of the acid sites. Zeolites, especially HZSM-5, are well-known for their high activity and shape-selectivity in alcohol dehydration. While they efficiently convert bio-alcohols to olefins, their practical application is hindered by coke formation, which limits long-term stability. Moreover, their strong acidity promotes side reactions such as cracking, reducing the selectivity toward target butene isomers [13]. ZSM-5 catalysts exhibit high dehydration activity for butanol, but their strong Brønsted acidity often leads to undesired side reactions, such as cracking, which reduces selectivity toward butenes. For instance, acidic ZSM-5 (SiAl = 280) yielded only 24.0 wt% butenes, alongside a significant 37.2 wt% of C₃–C₅ olefins due to cracking [14]. Another study reported a high conversion rate but low butene selectivity, which was attributed to the formation of lighter gases and heavier hydrocarbons [15]. To enhance butene selectivity, recent efforts have concentrated on modifying the acidity of H-ZSM-5 using techniques such as dealumination and desilication [16]. Several non-zeolite solid acid catalysts—such as γ-Al2O3, SiO2–Al2O3, tungstated zirconia, and heteropolyacids (HPAs) [17–19], ferrierite [20,21], TiO2-supported silica [22], vanadium phosphate [23], H₄SiW₁₂O₄₀/SiO₂ [24], phosphate-modified carbon nanotubes [25], WO₃/ZrO₂ [18] and carbon-based catalysts also containing phosphate groups [26] have also been explored for the dehydration of butanol to butenes. Therefore, the design of solid acid catalysts that combine high activity, selectivity, thermal stability, and resistance to deactivation remains a significant ongoing challenge. MCM-41 and other ordered mesoporous materials are effective dispersion media for active single oxides, offering enhanced catalytic performance due to their high surface area, large pore volume, and uniform pore size distribution [27]. Their structured porosity supports efficient loading of active elements and facilitates reactant diffusion, making them well-suited for liquid-phase oxidation. Additionally, embedding transition metals with in the mesoporous framework further improves catalytic efficiency. The large pore surface area of MCM-41 materials allows for the loading of the active element [28–30]. Ceria (CeO₂) is a highly promising metal oxide widely utilized in various applications, particularly in catalysis, due to its oxygen mobility as a facile transition between the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox states has been widely recognized as a key factor in numerous catalytic processes, acid-base characteristics, and redox properties [31]. Oxygen vacancies significantly affect electrical structure, O2 adsorption, redox behavior, surface active sites, and catalytic performance [32]. Fe-supported catalysts have excellent physical and chemical characteristics, making them suitable for processes including H2 adsorption and alcohol dehydration [33]. Iron oxide is a cost-effective, abundant, and environmentally friendly dopant for ceria oxides. It has excellent redox properties and can capture As5+, Cr6+, and organic dyes from wastewater [34]. Furthermore, cerium–iron binary oxides have demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance in the partial oxidation of methane to syngas, exhibiting high stability [35,36]. Additionally, Fe–Ce mixed oxides have shown remarkable efficiency in various catalytic and photocatalytic applications, including the degradation of organic pollutants [37], oxidation of mercury in the presence of ammonia, CO oxidation [38], and the total oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). They are also highly effective in catalytic soot combustion and play a vital role in several hydrogen production processes, such as the water-gas shift reaction [39], hydrocarbon reforming [40], thermochemical water splitting [41], and steam gasification of lignocellulosic biomass [42]. In this study, a series of CeO₂-Fe₂O₃/MCM-41 solid acid catalysts were prepared by dispersing different loadings (3, 10, 20, and 30 wt%) of CeO₂-Fe₂O₃ precursors into mesoporous MCM-41, followed by calcination at 550 °C for 3 hours under static air. The synthesized catalysts were thoroughly characterized using standard bulk and surface analysis techniques. Their catalytic efficiency was evaluated in the gas-phase dehydration of iso-butanol to butene. Results revealed a strong dependence of catalytic activity on surface structure and textural properties. The CeO₂–Fe₂O₃/MCM-41 system serves as a cost-efficient and highly tunable catalyst, where the synergistic interaction between ceria and iron oxide generates predominantly Lewis acid sites alongside a minor fraction of Brønsted acid sites. This optimized acid distribution promotes the selective E1-type elimination pathway, efficiently converting iso-butanol to butene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents all chemicals and reagents used in this study are specified in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Synthesis of CFO (CeO2-Fe2O3)/MCM catalyst materials the detailed synthesis protocols for the CFO/MCM catalysts are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Characterization the characterization techniques employed for the synthesized materials are thoroughly described in the Supporting Information. 2.4 Acidity measurement Surface acidity measurements for the catalysts were performed via the conversion reaction of isopropanol, which was carried out according to the previously described method [43–46]. The strength and distribution of acidic sites were investigated by exposing the most active catalyst to pyridine (PY) vapors in an evacuated desiccator for five days. After saturation, the catalyst was evaluated for IPA dehydration over a range of reaction temperatures. The desorption of pyridine (PY) over a range of reaction temperatures indicates the strength of acidic sites present on the catalyst surface. Pyridine-adsorbed Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (PY-FTIR) was then used to quantify and differentiate between Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. 2.5 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance of the synthesized composite catalysts was assessed for the vapor-phase dehydration of Iso-butanol using chromatographic analysis with a flame ionization detector (FID) on a Unicam Pro GC2000 [44,47,48]. In a typical experiment, 100 mg of catalyst was used within a temperature range of 120–350 °C under a nitrogen (N₂) atmosphere as a carrier gas and the total flow rate was 100 ml min−1, 2.8 % iso-butanol (IBA) in the gas feed and space time (GHSV60,000mlg−1h−1). For calculation, the following formulas were used: IBA conversion (%) =  IBA in − IBA out IBA in × 100 Butene (BuY) Selectivity (%) = butene butene + other products × 100 Butene Yield (%) = conversion × Selectivity 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD analysis The low-angle XRD patterns of CeO2-Fe2O3/M550 catalysts with varying CFO loadings, shown in Fig. 1(A), exhibit typical diffraction peaks at (100), (110), and (200), confirming that all CFO-supported catalysts share the same hexagonal arrangement of uniform mesopores as MCM41. The sharp peaks confirm the preservation of ordered mesoporous structures. This stability, despite different CFO loadings, is highly desirable since the mesoporous framework of MCM41 is often susceptible to degradation with the addition of CFO species [35,49]. The absence of significant diffraction peaks in the 10°-90° range confirms the presence of amorphous silica in both pure MCM41 and CFO/MCM41 catalysts. Importantly, no diffraction peaks corresponding to CeFeO3, CeO2, or Fe2O3 phases were observed. Additionally, the broad peak at 25°, typically associated with mesoporous silica, significantly diminished as the CFO loading increased. These observations suggest that CFO or mixed oxides are highly dispersed or present as nanoparticles too small or amorphous to be detected by XRD [47,50]. 3.1.2 ATR-FTIR analysis The ATR-FTIR spectra of the binary oxide CFO 550 are presented in Fig. 1(B). The spectra of the calcined composites (3–30 % CFO/M550), along with the corresponding calcined blank MCM, exhibit characteristic bands associated with MCM-type silica materials. Specifically, bands at 1224 and 1060 cm⁻¹ correspond to asymmetric stretching of Si–O–Si (νas), while the band at 960 cm⁻¹ is assigned to asymmetric stretching of Si–OH (νas). Additionally, a band at 795 cm⁻¹ is attributed to symmetric Si–O–Si stretching (νs), and the band at 450 cm⁻¹ corresponds to Si–O–Si bending (δ). Two additional bands observed at 3400 and 3200 cm⁻¹ are attributed to adsorbed water and ammonia [47]. The absence of peaks at 1480, 2850, and 2921 cm⁻¹ , which correspond to symmetric C-H and asymmetric CH₂ vibrations, confirms the complete removal of CTAB during calcination [48]. Absorption bands at 450 and 516 cm⁻¹ reflect Fe-O-Fe deformation, Fe-O stretching vibrations, and Ce-O stretching vibrations [49,51]. Moreover, a broad band at 1070 and 3443 cm⁻¹ is assigned to the stretching and bending vibrations of hydroxyl groups from surface-adsorbed water [50]. 3.1.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the surface elemental composition and the various chemical states of both the blank MCM-41 and the 10CFO/M550 supported catalyst. The elemental survey spectra for the blank MCM-41 revealed the presence of carbon (C), oxygen (O), and silicon (Si), while the 10CFO/M550 catalyst exhibited additional elements, namely iron (Fe) and cerium (Ce), alongside C, O, and Si. In the binding energy spectrum shown in the Fig. 2(A), the Si2p binding energies for the pristine MCM-41 were found within the range of 103–104.5 eV, indicating the presence of Si–O bonds, which are characteristic of mesoporous silica materials like MCM-41 [52]. Oxygen contribution was observed through the O1s binding energies, centered between 533 and 534.3 eV for the blank MCM-41. The 533 eV peak is attributed to OH groups in Si–OH bonds, while the 534 eV peak is associated with oxygen in Si–O–Si linkages [53]. The deconvoluted C1s peak, which can be resolved into three distinct peaks with binding energies at 288.22 eV, 285.8 eV, and 284.8 eV. These peaks correspond to O–CO, C–O, and C–C bonds, respectively [54]. The XPS analysis of the C 1 s region for the 10CFO/M550 catalyst was deconvoluted into three components with binding energies of 288.2, 285.8, and 284.8 eV, which were closely aligned with those detected in MCM550, as illustrated in Fig. 2(B). Additionally, the O 1 s spectrum of the 10CFO/M550 material was fitted with three peaks at 532, 533, and 530 eV [55]. The peak at 529.0 eV corresponds to lattice oxygen in Ce and Fe oxides, while the 532.1 eV peak is attributed to oxygen atoms bonded to silicon. XPS analysis was also used to investigate the relative proportions and oxidation states of Ce, Fe, and O in the Fe-Ce binary oxides. The Ce 3d XPS spectra displayed two characteristic spin-orbit multiplets, Ce 3d₅/₂ and Ce 3d₃/₂, which were resolved into eight components with binding energies approximately at 916, 907, 900, 898, 888, and 882 eV. These peaks indicate the presence of both Ce3+ and Ce4+ oxidation states, with the peaks at 882.2 and 900.1 eV corresponding to Ce3+, while those between 888 and 916.1 eV are associated with Ce⁴⁺[49,56]. The Fe 2p spectrum, two distinct peaks were identified at 711.1 and 724.7 eV, corresponding to Fe 2p₃/₂ and Fe 2p₁/₂, respectively. Moreover, the existence of both Fe2+ and Fe3+ species in the sample was verified by the appearance of two satellite peaks at 713.2 and 718.9 eV [51]. 3.1.4 Assessment of the nano composites' texture N2-physisorption isotherms of with different ratios of 3–30 % CFO binary oxides loaded MCM 550 matrix along with blank MCM550 are presented in Fig. 3 (A). The isotherms of the calcined blank MCM550 exhibit type IV isotherms, which is characteristic of MCM-41 mesoporous materials [43,55]. All synthesized Catalyst supported display type IV isotherms with well-defined. As the loading ratio increased, the hysteresis loops of the composites became progressively wider. At lower loading levels (3CFO/MCM), the loops exhibited type H 1 features, indicating the presence of wider mesopores due to voids exist within the uniformly shaped MCM-41 spheres. Conversely, at higher loading ratios (10, 20, and 30 CFO/MCM), type H 2 hysteresis was observed, suggesting structural alterations. For composites, the BET surface area (S BET ) values were 1157,1147, 1102, 900, and 804 m²/g for blank MCM, 3, 10, 20, and 30 CFO/MCM, respectively, Total pore volume, V p , in the range of (0.677–0.7534 cm3g−1) and external surface area S t values (21.8, 41.8 and 71.5) where obtained for the blank MCM and supported catalysts were obtained, respectively. Further textural data are cited in Table 1. It is clear that total pore volume and external surface values are following the same order observed for SBET surface area. The isotherm analysis confirmed that the MCM-41 structure was largely preserved, suggesting that the introduction of the binary oxides precursor contributed to its stabilization against sintering during calcination. However, S BET values gradually declined as the CFO ratios increased, primarily due to pore blockage and partial structural degradation. The retention of a relatively high surface area was attributed to the fine dispersion of nano sized CeO2 and Fe2O3 binary oxides within the MCM matrix. This indicates the expansion of small mesopores in the composites during the formation process. The average pore width (P W ) of the catalysts was determined using the 4 V T /S BET method and the BJH method, as presented in Table 1. The pore width distribution (PWD) for MCM and the supported catalysts calcined at 550°C is shown in Fig. 3(B), respectively. The PWD of the supported catalysts was analyzed. For the blank MCM support and the 3, 10, 20, and 30 CFO/M catalysts, the pore width distributions of the 3–30 CFO/MCM 550 calcined composites peaked between 21.6 and 35.5 Å, in contrast to 19.7 Å for the blank material. Fig. 3(B) illustrates the pore width distribution within the mesoporous range. This trend suggests that as the CFO loading within the mesoporous matrix increased, the PWD reached its maximum within a progressively broader mesoporous range. 3.1.5 Texture morphology of the composites Fig. 4 (b-f), The TEM micrographs of 10CFO/M550 reveal the well-organized porous structure of MCM-41, characterized by their spherical shape and well-organized channels. The successful embedding of CFO into these pores leads to the formation of numerous tiny, irregular, separate, or aggregated CFO nanoparticles, appearing as irregular dark shadows. Notably, the loading of CeO₂ and Fe₂O₃ species does not affect the pore structure, confirming the stability of the MCM-41 framework. Furthermore, the Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) analysis confirms the presence of a disordered 3D nanostructure. Fig. 4 (g), where no crystalline (amorphous) CFO oxides phases into MCM frame wok. As shown in Fig. 4 (a, h-m), EDX elemental mapping was conducted on 10CFO/M550 catalyst. The 10CFO/M550 catalyst showed C, O, Si, Fe, and Ce confirming the homogeneous distribution of Fe and Ce within the mesoporous MCM-41 structure. These results demonstrate that CeO₂ and Fe₂O₃ were successfully incorporated into the MCM-41 support, achieving a high density of finely dispersed Fe and Ce uniformly throughout the MCM-41 pores. Examination of the elemental maps confirms that Ce and Fe are homogeneously distributed within the pores of the MCM-41 matrix, with no formation of bulk phases. In contrast, for the blank MCM supports, the EDX spectrum indicated the presence of C, O, and Si as shown in Fig.S1. 3.1.6 Thermal (TGA and DTA) analysis TGA–DTG analysis of catalyst composites 3 CFO/M 550 and 10 CFO/M 550, along with the blank MCM, was conducted under both nitrogen (N₂) and oxygen (O₂) atmospheres, as illustrated in the respective Fig.S2 (A and B), with numerical data provided in Table.S1 and Table.S2. The overall weight loss observed from room temperature (RT) to 750°C for both the composites and blank MCM proceeded through three distinct decomposition stages. The measured weight loss values were 44.7 %, 44.7 %, and 46.7 % in an N₂ atmosphere, while in an O₂ atmosphere, the values were 44.6 %, 48.6 %, and 47.3 %.Similar to the previously observed behavior in blank MCM-41 [57,58], The first decomposition stage below 170 °C is assignable to loss of adsorbed water. The second decomposition stage, occurring between 170°C and 400°C, was primarily associated with the removal of the template. The major weight loss peaks were observed at 270°C and 335°C for 3 CFO/MCM and at 263°C and 338°C for 10 CFO/MCM in an N₂ atmosphere. Under an O₂ atmosphere, the corresponding peaks appeared at 259°C and 318°C for 3 CFO/MCM and at 252°C and 291°C for 10 CFO/MCM. The final decomposition step, occurring between 300°C and 500°C, resulted in weight losses of 7.7 % and 11.5 % for the composites in an N₂ atmosphere, and 7.9 % and 11.7 % in an O₂ atmosphere. This weight reduction is attributed to the combustion of residual organic components. The overall mass loss between RT and 750°C was greater in an O₂ atmosphere than in an N2 atmosphere. This is likely due to the oxidation of Ce3+ to Ce4+, which, in conjunction with O2, serves as a strong oxidizing agent, accelerating the decomposition of adsorbed materials. Additionally, DTG curves recorded under N₂ were shifted to higher temperatures compared to those in O₂, indicating that decomposition in N₂ occurred primarily through degradation rather than combustion. In contrast, combustion in an O₂ atmosphere was not solely driven by atmospheric oxygen but was also facilitated by Ce4+, which further enhanced the oxidation process. DTA analysis was conducted at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in both nitrogen (N₂) and oxygen (O₂) atmospheres for the blank MCM, as well as the composite materials 3CFO/MCM and 10CFO/MCM, as shown in the corresponding figures Fig.S3 (A and B). A broad endothermic peak was detected below 200°C across all samples. Furthermore, exothermic peaks were identified at 366°C, 344°C, and 260°C for 3 CFO/MCM, 10 CFO/MCM, and 30 CFO/MCM, respectively, in an N₂ atmosphere. In an O2 atmosphere, exothermic peaks appeared at 350°C for blank MCM, 320°C for 3 CFO/MCM, and 293°C for 10 CFO/MCM. These results indicate that a higher loading ratio enhances the interaction between the surfactant and nitrate, leading to a decrease in combustion temperature. Moreover, at elevated loading levels, as seen in 30 CFO/MCM, the shoulder peak broadens, suggesting that while degradation is the dominant process at lower ratios, higher ratios promote both faster degradation and combustion. 3.2 Assessment of surface acidity for the catalysts The surface acidity of the catalysts were assessed using the isopropanol conversion method, a well-established technique for investigating the acid-base properties of solid materials [44,59,60]. The catalytic dehydration of IPA over the surface of the synthesized catalyst materials, including blank MCM and CFO/M550-supported catalysts with varying compositions, was investigated at 200°C, as presented in Fig. 5 (A). According to the results, the composite materials exhibit extremely high catalytic activity when compared to the catalytic activity measured for pure CFO and blank MCM support. The order of the catalytic activity was 10CFOM > 20CFOM > 30CFOM > > Pure CFO > blank MCM. With a 94 % conversion rate at 200 °C and 100 % selectivity for propene production, the 10CFO/MCM550 catalyst had the best catalytic activity. As illustrated in Fig. 5(A), the improved catalytic material (10CFOM550) was investigated at temperatures range (120–250ºC). Over the 10CFOM550, the conversion to propene is improved by raising the catalytic reaction's temperature. While the dehydration of isopropanol provides an overall measure of surface acidity, further analysis was conducted to determine the type and strength of acidic sites [61]. These findings were further validated by PY-FTIR analysis Fig. 5(B), and the corresponding concentrations of both Lewis (L) and Brønsted (B) acid sites, as calculated according to reference [62], are summarized in Table S3. As shown in Fig. 5(B), The strong absorption bands observed at 1444 and 1595 cm−1correspond to coordinately bonded pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, The band at 1488 cm−1 is attributed to the interaction between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the catalyst, whereas the band at approximately 1633 cm−1 correspond to pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites [63,64]. These results indicate that the 10CFO//MCM surface contains both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, with Lewis acid sites being predominant, as shown in Table.S3 [65]. The results indicated that Lewis acid sites were predominant, as evidenced by their higher percentage compared to Brønsted sites and their greater quantity (4.5 mmol/g and 0.744 mmol/g for Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively). The concentrations of acid sites were estimated based on the integrated areas under the characteristic IR peaks [66]. To further investigate the location and strength of acidic sites, the most active catalyst (10CFO/MCM550) was exposed to pyridine (PY) vapors in an evacuated desiccator for five days Fig. S4A. Subsequently, the effect of reaction temperature on IPA dehydration was evaluated using the 10CFO/MCM550 catalyst pre-saturated with PY and DMPY. The results show that adsorption of PY or DMPY significantly reduces IPA conversion compared to the unsaturated catalyst. However, as the reaction temperature increases to 225 °C, the catalyst gradually recovers its acidity and catalytic activity. These findings suggest that 10CFO/MCM550 primarily contains weak to intermediate acid sites. Subsequently, the pre-saturated catalyst was tested for IPA dehydration across a range of temperatures Fig. S4B. Desorption analysis revealed that most PY molecules were released between 200 and 250°C,indicating that the acidic sites are primarily of weak to intermediate strength [59,60,67–69]. 3.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic dehydration of butanol to butene was investigated over 3–30 CFO/M550 catalysts and the MCM support within a temperature range of 150–400°C. The butanol conversion and butene selectivity are graphically depicted in Fig. 6. It was observed that all catalysts achieved 100 % selectivity for butene. For the MCM matrix support, the catalytic activity for butanol conversion reached 50 % and 80 %, corresponding to butene formation rates of 24.5 and 39.2 mmol g⁻¹h⁻¹ at 326°C and 359°C, respectively. At 313°C, 291°C, 283°C, and 270°C, the 3, 10, 20, and 30CFO/MCM catalysts each achieved 50 % conversion. Similarly, at 354°C, 342°C, 340°C, and 324°C, the same catalysts showed 80 % conversion. All catalysts demonstrated 100 % selectivity for butene over the temperature range tested, confirming their efficiency. The 10CFO/MCM catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity, achieving conversion rates of 82 % at 327°C and 92 % at 350°C. Correspondingly, the butene production rates at these temperatures were 40.2 mmol g⁻¹ h⁻¹ and 45.1 mmol g⁻¹ h⁻¹ , respectively. The improved catalytic performance can be correlated to the increasing of surface oxygenated groups (as shown by XRD results) and the formation of new surface CeO2 and Fe2O3 binary oxides (as shown by XPS results). The impact of butanol concentration in a nitrogen gas flow stream, expressed as butanol% (v/v), on butanol conversion and butene selectivity was studied using the most active catalyst. At a nitrogen flow rate of 100 ml/min and a temperature of 350°C with 2.8 % (v/v) butanol concentration (WHSV ∼ 5.5 h⁻¹), a high butanol conversion of 92 % and complete selectivity for butene formation were achieved shown in Fig. 7A. However, as the butanol concentration gradually increased to 5 % (v/v), the butanol conversion progressively declined to 50 %, while the selectivity for butene remained at 100 %. The study explored the impact of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) on the performance of the 10CFO/MCM catalyst at 350°C, with GHSV ranging from 100,000 to 160,000 ml g−1 h−1. By adjusting the gas flow rate while maintaining a fixed butanol concentration (v/v%) in the feed, as shown in Fig. 7B, it was observed that the conversion efficiency declined from 92 % to 66 % as GHSV increased within this range. This decline is attributed to the reduced contact time, which limits butanol adsorption on the catalyst surface. The recyclability of 10CFO/MCM was evaluated under optimal reaction conditions. Iso-butanol conversion slightly decreased from 92 % to 84 % over five cycles, while butene selectivity remained at 100 % Fig. 8. Approximately 8 % of the activity was lost after five cycles of regeneration. The long-term stability of 10CFO/MCM550 for butene production was also evaluated at 350ºC, as shown in Fig.S5. The activation energy (Ea) for the catalytic dehydration of isobutanol to butene was determined using Arrhenius plots Fig. S6. The results also demonstrate that the catalyst maintains stable activity over 120 hours of continuous operation, showing nearly unchanged performance and 100 % selectivity toward butene. The calculated Ea values were 25.16 kJ/mol for the blank MCM and 12.82 kJ/mol for the 10CFO/MCM550 supported catalyst. These results confirm that the activation energy for the reaction is lower when using the 10CFO/MCM550-supported catalyst compared to the blank MCM support. This reduction in Ea explains the enhanced catalytic activity of the10CFO/MCM550-supported catalyst for butene production. The catalytic performance of the 10CFO/MCM550 catalyst, introduced as a novel material, has been compared with other recently reported catalysts for the catalytic dehydration of butanol to butene, as shown in Table2. Scheme1 shows a schematic representation of the suggested mechanism for butanol dehydration to butene. Alcohol dehydration reactions are facilitated by acidic sites. In the case of butanol dehydration to butene (including 1-butene and the two isomers of 2-butene), the reaction typically occurs under atmospheric pressure and mild temperature conditions [70,71]. The proposed mechanism for isobutanol dehydration to butene may involve E1, E2, and E1cB elimination pathways [72,73].This process is strongly associated with the catalytic activity and the distribution of 1-butene, trans-2-butene, and cis-2-butene, which are governed by the acid-base characteristics of the catalysts. Incorporating CeO₂ and Fe₂O₃ species into the MCM-41 matrix enhances its catalytic performance by increasing surface oxygenation and acidity. The dehydration of isobutanol over CFO/MCM catalysts predominantly follows an E1 elimination mechanism, where Brønsted acid sites initiate carbocation formation with the removal of the hydroxyl group from isobutanol and Lewis acid sites stabilize intermediates, the carbocation loses a proton leading to alkene formation. PY-FTIR confirms the presence of both Lewis acid sites (major) and Brønsted sites (minor) in 10CFO/MCM-41 catalyst. XPS analysis revealed shifts in the binding energies of Ce and Fe species, indicating strong metal–support interactions and alterations in electronic structure that affect both the strength and type of acid sites.The synergistic effect plays a crucial role in enhancing the acidity of these catalysts, where the proposed active sites involve the redox pairs Ce³ ⁺/Ce⁴⁺ and Fe²⁺/Fe³[74,75], respectively. Combined with PY-FTIR analysis, the XPS findings offer complementary insights that establish a clear link between surface acidity and catalytic performance, thereby reinforcing the plausibility of the proposed E1 elimination mechanism. 4 Conclusion This study presents the synthesis of environmentally friendly catalyst/support systems and evaluates their effectiveness in the catalytic dehydration of butanol to butene. A series of CeO₂–Fe₂O₃ binary oxides (3–30 wt%) supported on mesoporous MCM-41 were prepared, which led to notable enhancements in surface area, porosity, and surface acidity. Among them, the 10CFO/MCM550 catalyst exhibited the best performance, achieving isobutanol conversion rates of 82 % at 300 °C and 92 % at 350 °C, along with complete selectivity to butene (100 %) and stable operation over 120 h on stream. Importantly, the activation energy (Ea) for dehydration decreased significantly—from 25.16 kJ/mol for bare MCM-41–12.82 kJ/mol for 10CFO/MCM550—highlighting the superior catalytic reactivity of the modified system. The choice of support material was shown to play a vital role in influencing both catalytic activity and long-term stability. Critical factors included hydrothermal stability, oxygen mobility, and uniform dispersion of the active metal species. Notably, the Fe–O–Ce interface facilitated the coupling of Ce3+/Ce4+ and Fe2+/Fe3+ redox pairs, enhancing both acidity and activity. This synergistic interaction is proposed to be the driving force behind the formation of active sites essential for efficient isobutanol dehydration. The resulting optimized acid–base properties arising from Ce–Fe interactions position this system as a promising and sustainable catalyst for butene production. coredata.dc:description: CeO₂–Fe₂O₃ binary oxides were effectively incorporated into mesoporous spherical silica (MCM-41) via a sol–gel technique. The resultant CFO/MCM-41 nanocomposites, with metal loadings ranging from 3 to 30 wt%, were subsequently calcined at 550 °C and assessed as catalysts for the gas-phase dehydration of isobutyl alcohol. Structural and surface analyses using XRD, TG-DTA, ATR-FTIR, BET, TEM, EDX, XPS, and pyridine-adsorbed FTIR confirmed the formation of thermally stable, well-dispersed active phases, as well as the presence of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The differences in catalytic activity among these nanocomposites were closely linked to variations in their acidity. Among all the catalysts, the 10 wt% CeFeO₃/MCM-41 sample demonstrated the best performance at 350 °C, achieving approximately 92 % isobutanol conversion, 100 % selectivity toward isobutylene, and a butene production rate of 45.10 mmol g⁻¹ h⁻¹ . The catalyst also showed excellent stability across five reuse cycles. The outstanding catalytic performance and stability were directly correlated with the material's enhanced structural integrity and optimized textural properties. Furthermore, XPS analysis revealed that the Ce3 +/Ce4+ and Fe2+/Fe3+ redox states, modulated by Ce–Fe interactions, played a crucial role in tuning the catalyst’s acidity and catalytic performance.

coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of CeO2 and Fe2O3 species on mesoporous silica as efficient catalysts for the vapor-phase dehydration of iso-butyl alcohol to isobutylene
